node.title: Sally Ann Howes, Star of ‘Chitty Chitty Bang Bang,’ Dies at 91
node.alt: Sally Ann Howes in London in 1968.
node.description: The English-born actress captivated children in the 1968 film, which became a holiday favorite. It was one of around 140 productions she appeared in during a six-decade career.
node.content: ["Sally Ann Howes, an English-born grande dame of American and British musical comedy who captivated children as Truly Scrumptious in the 1968 film \u201cChitty Chitty Bang Bang,\u201d featuring a magic jalopy that floats and flies into fantasy adventures, died on Sunday in a hospital in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla . She was 91.", "John Lloyd, a manager of Northwood Funeral Home and Crematory in West Palm Beach, Fla., confirmed her death in a telephone interview.", "Born into show business, the daughter of a popular London comedian and his singing-actress wife, Ms. Howes was cast in her first movie at 12 and had a stage, screen and television career that spanned six decades. She starred in some 140 productions \u2014 musicals and plays in New York and London, and Hollywood and television movies and mini-series.", "She toured Britain and America in musicals; sang at the White House for Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson; was a frequent guest on television game and talk shows; became a Barbie doll; sang operettas; and later in life lectured, made documentaries and raised funds for AIDS research and other charities.", "Ms. Howes had starred in a dozen British films and several American musicals, including \u201cMy Fair Lady,\u201d \u201cWhat Makes Sammy Run?\u201d and \u201cBrigadoon,\u201d when, toward the end of 1968, a tumultuous year of assassinations, a divisive war in Vietnam and widespread political protests, a madcap movie opened in Britain and the United States as a zany antidote for the troubled world.", "Based loosely on a children\u2019s book by Ian Fleming, creator of the James Bond spy tales, \u201cChitty Chitty Bang Bang,\u201d a British production, starred Dick Van Dyke as a widowed nutty inventor and Ms. Howes as the love interest, Truly Scrumptious, who with his two children and his marvelous flying-boat car, journey to the land of Vulgaria to battle the nasty tyrant Baron Bomburst.", "Critics were mixed about the Ken Hughes-Roald Dahl film, but children were ecstatic. Its popularity spawned mass marketing phenomena on both sides of the Atlantic, with Truly Scrumptious Barbie dolls, lunchboxes and toys, and a revival of Edwardian fashions worn by the cast.", "The film critic Roger Ebert called it \u201cabout the best two-hour children\u2019s movie you could hope for.\u201d Renata Adler, in The New York Times, said: \u201cThere is nothing coy, or stodgy or too frightening about the film. And this year, when it has seemed highly doubtful that children ought to go to the movies at all, \u2018Chitty Chitty Bang Bang\u2019 sees to it that none of the audiences\u2019 terrific eagerness to have a good time is betrayed or lost.\u201d", "While it lost money initially, the film became a perennial children\u2019s favorite and made Ms. Howes an international film star, her fame renewed every Christmas in videos and DVDs and for the nostalgia buffs. It was nominated in 2006 for the American Film Institute\u2019s Greatest Movie Musicals.", "Ms. Howes moved to New York in 1958 when she married to the composer-lyricist Richard Adler and made her Broadway debut in Lerner and Loewe\u2019s \u201cMy Fair Lady.\u201d She replaced the original star, Julie Andrews, in the role of Eliza Doolittle, the smudged Cockney flower girl who is transformed by the demanding speech lessons of Professor Henry Higgins to a radiant lady from a draggletailed guttersnipe.", "Audiences and most critics adored her as George Bernard Shaw\u2019s gamine. \u201cSally Ann Howes, the current Eliza, is a strikingly beautiful young lady with a rapturous voice that sounds like Julie Andrews,\u201d Brooks Atkinson wrote in The Times. \u201cRadiating intelligence and guile,\u201d he went on, \u201cshe is an alert and versatile actress.\u201d", "Ms. Howes returned to Broadway in 1961 for \u201cKwamina,\u201d a musical written for her by Mr. Adler. An interracial love story set in Africa with an almost entirely Black cast, it was apparently too contentious in the turbulent early civil rights era, and closed after 32 performances.", "In 1962, Ms. Howes starred in a limited-run City Center revival of \u201cBrigadoon,\u201d a fantasy about two American boys who stumble upon a Scottish village that comes to life only one day every century.", "\u201cSally Ann Howes has grown accustomed to Lerner and Loewe songs,\u201d Milton Esterow said in a review for The Times. \u201cShe has grace, beauty and a lovely voice.\u201d Since \u201cBrigadoon\u201d was soon to vanish, Mr. Esterow suggested, \u201cBroadway should hurry and find a new show for Miss Howes. Otherwise some smart gentlemen in Scotland might decide to nominate her for public office.\u201d", "In 1964, Ms. Howes joined Robert Alda and Steve Lawrence in Budd Schulberg\u2019s \u201cWhat Makes Sammy Run?\u201d a Broadway musical about a ruthless young man who betrays friends and lovers to scheme his way to the top of a Hollywood studio. The show ran 540 performances, although Ms. Howes, pressed by other engagements, left after a year.", "Throughout the 1960s, she turned increasingly to television, appearing on the Perry Como, Dinah Shore, Jack Paar and Ed Sullivan shows, and in roles on \u201cThe Bell Telephone Hour,\u201d the \u201cKraft Music Hall\u201d and \u201cUnited States Steel Hour.\u201d She also had roles in \u201cMission: Impossible,\u201d \u201cMarcus Welby, M.D.\u201d and \u201cBracken\u2019s World.\u201d", "Ms. Howes toured Britain in 1973 in \u201cThe King and I,\u201d and the United States in 1978 in \u201cThe Sound of Music.\u201d In the 1970s and 1980s, she sang operettas like \u201cBlossom Time\u201d and \u201cThe Merry Widow\u201d in American regional theaters. A half-century after her triumph as Eliza Doolittle, Ms. Howes toured the United States in 2007 in \u201cMy Fair Lady,\u201d playing Mrs. Higgins, the mother of Henry Higgins. It was her 64th year in show business.", "Sally Ann Howes was born in London on July 20, 1930, to the comedian Bobby Howes and the actress Patricia Malone. Her grandfather, Capt. J.A.E. Malone, directed stage musicals; an uncle, Pat Malone, was an actor. Sally Ann and her older brother, Peter, a musician, grew up in a prosperous household with nannies and her parents\u2019 theatrical peers. During World War II, the family moved to its country estate in Essendon, 20 miles north of London, for the duration.", "Her acting in school plays and her family connections attracted an agent, and in 1943 she appeared with Stewart Granger in her first movie, \u201cThursday\u2019s Child.\u201d It launched her career. She played children\u2019s roles in \u201cDead of Night\u201d (1945) with Michael Redgrave, and \u201cAnna Karenina\u201d (1948) with Vivien Leigh. At 18, she appeared with John Mills in \u201cThe History of Mr. Polly\u201d (1949).", "In the 1950s, she began taking stage roles and, with singing lessons to lower her high-pitched voice, performed in West End musicals, including \u201cPaint Your Wagon\u201d (1953), with her father, and in the stage drama, \u201cA Hatful of Rain.\u201d ", "Ms. Howes\u2019 marriage in 1950 to Maxwell Coker ended in divorce in 1953. She divorced Mr. Adler in 1966. Her marriage in 1969 to A. Morgan Maree III, a financier, also ended in divorce. In the 1970s, she married the literary agent Douglas W. Rae, who died this year. ", "Ms. Howes, who had homes in London and West Palm Beach, Fla., joined 1,500 film fans on a 2013 Turner Classic Movies cruise that featured \u201cChitty Chitty Bang Bang,\u201d and she discussed her life as an entertainer.", "\u201cThe moment you hit 45 \u2014 now it\u2019s 55 \u2014 your career changes,\u201d she said. \u201cYou have to rethink everything, and you have to adjust. I was always aware of it because of the people I was brought up with. We saw careers go up and down and be killed off. I\u2019ve never prepared for anything. I\u2019ve always jumped into the next thing, and therefore it\u2019s been a strange career. I enjoyed experimenting.\u201d"]
